reviewText:
As much as I like this little game I can't really recommend this game to anyone.

Frontline Tactics isn't really a bad game. Sure, it feels like it was someones first video game project they ever made and some stuff like graphics and sound design feels a bit... off considering the game was made in 2012. Part of the reason may be that the game was ported from mobile devices to PC.

But that's not really the problem here. The biggest nuisanse comes from the quite thin but still existent pay wall. You need to pay money in order to get powerful units right from the start or play the game for hours and grind your way slowly through quite tough missions in order to get more units. This isn't much of an issue since the game only offers fun for the first few hours and then slowly starts to lose the fun. Missions begin to be repetitive and not really challenging at all after getting your first powerful units and there aren't really many multiplayer players with good unit builds. So you are either stuck with an extremely boring single player or quite dead multi player. Your choice.

Oh and I almost forgot. One of the achievements requires for you to use real life money in to the game in order to unlock it... Quite the cash grab achievement for completionists.

After playing this game rather heavily for the last week or so I can safely say it is a solid little game to burn time on. Its especially well suited to those moods when you want to game, but also sit back and chill watching something on tv or even just playing with a pet while also distracting your mind.

Some call this game pay to win etc. I call BS. I dropped a meager 2 dollars on the DLC complete pack during a sale and that is more then enough of a leg up for even the least tactical minded player to push through the rough start and get ones groove going.

Im going to have to say that this is one of the most enjoyable little turn based tactical strategy games with some RPG character development Ive played since the classic fallout tactics and final fantasy tactics , a couple of my fave of the genre.

If your looking to start it Id personally wait for a nice discount sale on the DLC to give you that extra oomph, but its not some magic I win button.

Im also talking largely from the single player approach. I dont know exactly how the PVP maps play, but if they use your own soldier team then frankly Id not touch it till my squad feels complete from the solo campaign. By that I mean having a solid 5 man squad all with developed primary and 2ndary specialties, and at least the teir 3 weapon in each.

That is about where I started to feel like I was playing my characters rather then as the mere meat puppets they start out as in my eyes.

Seriesouly if you have any love for the genre, and a few bucks to drop during a sale on the DLC Id stress you DL the game and give it a few missions to pull you in.

I think many will be most surprised when they start seeing just how much each unit can be developed and customized over time to suit given play style approaches.

Ive re rolled a few characters including some of the pay for dlc guys, playing with comboes to find what I personally like.

For example I first tried making my medic a sniper but found the combo so slowed him down as to make him worthless. reviewText:
Frontline Tactics is a free-to-play squad level, turn-based tactical game where missions become available on a strategic regional map and missions take place on an isometric map based on one of several static locations (Fishing village, tank battle, etc).

The basic aim of the game is to complete missions on the game map with the soldiers you have available and the skills and weapons at their disposal.  As you complete more missions you earn credits which can be spent upgrade your team.  For every 5th mission completed, you get to unlock certain strategic options, such as more mission types (Liberate area, Defend area, Timed survival etc), more locations (maps) plus bonuses such as +credits or +team member slots.

Its basically a pay-to-pay game, with anything from squad members, solder proficiencies, soldier skills, equipment, weapons, weapon attachments being able to be purchased with in-game credits.  However you do not have to pay, credits can be earned while just playing through missions, which is what I have done.  Its slower, alot slower but, it just means you will have to play alot more missions to get you squad up to spec.

I have mixed feelings about about this game.  On one hand the gameplay is fiendishly addictive but, on the other hand it can be enormously frustrating to play.  Luckily its quite forgiving if you get your squad killed or fail a mission as all soldiers have infinite lives and you can replay missions when you lose.

What it does do really well is provide a great representation of squad scale tactical battles which are fun and furious and include: use of cover, crossfire, close and ranged combat, thrown explosives, use of camoflague, decent mission variety, overwatch, soldier perks & skills and a decent range of equipment and weapons.

What it doesnt do so well is that it isnt balanced on two levels.  It doesnt provide a fair challenge as in alot of missions you will be outnumbered, the enemy will move first in droves and sometimes they will move twice before you even do so and kill several of your men before they have even had a chance to move.  Secondly the rate at which you can upgrade is quite slow depending on your strategy.

However once you do put in a few hours and have completed around 40 missions you will have earned enough credits to have a decent team with dual proficiencies (rifles, smgs, close-combat, hand-to-hand, sniper or heavy weapons) with some armour, some may have grenades (stun, frags) even if your team will have basic skills (one for each proficiency) and basic weapons (which can be upgraded from late 80s to future-tech).  At this stage the game gets to be very enjoyable as even if your enemy gets the jump on you, you should be able to recover and lead your team to victory in most cases.

While I havent purchased any in-game credits I did buy the extra soldier dlcs when on sale, and they were more than worth it as you only start your team with 2 solders.

Overall the game is just about recommendable as it is more enjoyable than frustrating and worth the time of anyone who loved Jagged Alliance 2 or any game of that genre.

** Just be warned that if you are after 100% achievements there is one were you must buy £80/$100/100euros worth of credits just to unlock.  ^^ **

Ok, so after the first mission or so, it begins to take a really long time - not so bad ?  Well, also, you can't save during combat.  In fact, you can't save AFTER combat either, unless you manage to get back to a base.  On some games I could understand this ... on a game like F.T. where (turn-based) it takes you 6 hrs or more to finish a mission, it's nigh unforgivable.  Even so, that STILL wouldn't be so bad, except ...

Whoever designed the layout of some of these missions was a sadistic @#$!  Don't get me wrong here - fighting's great, you can change up weaponry fairly easily, standard stand, crouch, crawl, walk, run ... but when you look at the map and the checkpoints, then eyeball the overall terrain itself, it'd be nice to think if you decided to go one way to get to, say, Checkpoint X on the map, you wouldn't discover 90% of the way there that some hip-high barrels had been placed strategically along the way to ensure that you COULDN'T get there from here ... The iso view is annoying in that way b/c of the level of obscurity you have to deal with (i.e., is that alleyway running behind that building blocked, or is there a clearcut way to get down it and out the other side?).  Generally, any time you have to wonder about that answer in this game, assume the answer is a big fat NO.  The game delights in having you do an amazing amount of backtracking.  Granted, there are a few things you can crawl under.  But there's no climbing over or rolling barrels out of the way.  If you get to a hip high sandbagged wall, there's no way of removing said sandbags from your path so your vehicle can get through ( I tried dynamite even w/o any luck ).  Perhaps if you play the game in R.T. this wouldn't be nearly the hassle that it is in T.B.  Just my 2 cents.
